newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore shares end weaker, further falls seen.
newsitem.headline: Singapore shares end weaker, further falls seen.

text.p: Singapore shares closed down on Thursday and were expected to remain under pressure if an overnight fall on Wall Street combined with further fall out from efforts to prop up the ailing Thai baht, dealers said.
"If Wall Street falls overnight then you know we'll get hit," one dealer at a local firm said.
"The currency problem is not going to go away overnight," another dealer said.
The Straits Times Industrials Index (STII) saw 1.36 percent or 28.52 points lopped off by the close, ending at 2,069.74.
The 2,060 support level is seen by analysts as a key resistance point for the STII.
The sell down started after the Monetary Authority of Singapore stepped in to prop up the struggling baht and concerns grew among fund managers about their regional exposures.
With 177.8 million shares traded, losers trounced gainers 327 to 68 with banking stocks leading the fall.
DBS foreign lost Singapore $1.10 to S$17.90, OCBC foreign lost a dollar to S$17.90 and UOB foreign fell S$0.90 to S$14.60.
